com.gh.bmd.jrt.android.invocation

Class ContextInvocations

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.gh.bmd.jrt.android.invocation.ContextInvocations

  • public class ContextInvocations
extends Object
    Utility class for creating context invocation factory objects.

    Created by davide-maestroni on 5/1/15.

      • factoryOf

        @Nonnull
public static <INPUT,OUTPUT> ContextInvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factoryOf(@Nonnull
                                                                      Class<? extends ContextInvocation<INPUT,OUTPUT>> invocationClass)
        Builds and returns a new context invocation factory creating instances of the specified class.

        Note that inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes has both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        INPUT - the input data type.
        OUTPUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationClass - the invocation class.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.

      • factoryOf

        @Nonnull
public static <INPUT,OUTPUT> ContextInvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factoryOf(@Nonnull
                                                                      Class<? extends ContextInvocation<INPUT,OUTPUT>> invocationClass,
                                                                      @Nullable
                                                                      Object... args)
        Builds and returns a new context invocation factory creating instances of the specified class by passing the specified arguments to the class constructor.

        Note that inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes has both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        INPUT - the input data type.
        OUTPUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationClass - the invocation class.
        args - the invocation constructor arguments.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.

      • factoryOf

        @Nonnull
public static <INPUT,OUTPUT> ContextInvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factoryOf(@Nonnull
                                                                      ClassToken<? extends ContextInvocation<INPUT,OUTPUT>> invocationToken)
        Builds and returns a new context invocation factory creating instances of the specified class token.

        Note that class tokens of inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes has both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        INPUT - the input data type.
        OUTPUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationToken - the invocation class token.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.

      • factoryOf

        @Nonnull
public static <INPUT,OUTPUT> ContextInvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factoryOf(@Nonnull
                                                                      ClassToken<? extends ContextInvocation<INPUT,OUTPUT>> invocationToken,
                                                                      @Nullable
                                                                      Object... args)
        Builds and returns a new context invocation factory creating instances of the specified class token by passing the specified arguments to the class constructor.

        Note that class tokens of inner and anonymous classes can be passed as well. Remember however that Java creates synthetic constructors for such classes, so be sure to specify the correct arguments to guarantee proper instantiation. In fact, inner classes always have the outer instance as first constructor parameter, and anonymous classes has both the outer instance and all the variables captured in the closure.

        Type Parameters:
        INPUT - the input data type.
        OUTPUT - the output data type.
        Parameters:
        invocationToken - the invocation class token.
        args - the invocation constructor arguments.
        Returns:
        the invocation factory.

public static <INPUT,OUTPUT> InvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factoryTo(@Nonnull

                                                               @Nonnull
                                                               ContextInvocationFactory<INPUT,OUTPUT> factory)
        Converts the specified context invocation factory into a factory of invocations.
        Type Parameters:

        OUTPUT - the output data type.
